p: In the present study, the antiproliferative potential of PJ solvent fractions, namely, aqueous, methanol, acetone, and hexane, was investigated on HeLa cervical adenocarcinoma. HeLa cells were exposed to increasing concentrations of each tested plant sample (0.625, 1.25, 2.5, 5, and 10 mg/ml) for 24 h, and the cell viability was quantified using an MTS assay. Treating HeLa cells with 0.625, 1.25, 2.5, 5, and 10 mg/ml of PJ acetone fraction ( Figure 3(a)), cell viability significantly decreased ( p value < 0.0001) by approximately 90%. As demonstrated in Figure 3(b), hexane fraction decreased cell viability significantly ( p value < 0.0001) by approximately 90% at all tested concentrations except the lowest concentration (0.625 mg/ml). Treatment of HeLa cells with 2.5, 5, and 10 mg/ml of methanol fraction decreased cell viability significantly ( p value < 0.01) by approximately 90%, while the rest of the concentrations had no significant effect ( Figure 3(c)). As shown in Figure 3(d), water extract had no significant effect at all tested concentrations.
